generated_text: The structure of ice II is a key component of the understanding of the origin of the Earth’s core and the origin of life. The structure of ice II is also of fundamental importance to the understanding of the structure of the hydrate, which is a key component of the deep ocean. In this work, we report the structure of a hydrate, which is a mixture of water and neon. The structure of the hydrate is different from that of ice II, and the guest atoms are enclathrated in the host lattices. The structure of the hydrate is also different from that of the other hydrates, which are mixtures of water and other elements.

The mathematical structure of quantum theory is based on a set of axioms that are not categorical. This makes it difficult to use the theory as a foundation for mathematics. We provide a set of axioms for a category of functions between Hilbert spaces that are categorical and therefore can be used as a foundation. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the origin of parasitism and the evolution of the animal kingdom. (Show more)

The current pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2 has affected the lives of millions of people worldwide. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune response by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). In this study, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this evasion mechanism. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that mediates nuclear import of cargo proteins. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to block nuclear import of ISG mRNA. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be exploited by other viruses and may be a target for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on the channel: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of the channel, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of the channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion people by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of a growing population. This study shows that the variability of maize production will increase substantially in the future, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase dramatically. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The coexistence of species with different feeding preferences is a fundamental challenge in ecology. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the degree to which different species partition food resources at the species level. We also show that the degree of overlap in food-resource use between species is strongly related to the degree of overlap in the species’ resource use. These results suggest that the coexistence of species with different feeding preferences is not only a fundamental challenge in ecology but also that the degree of overlap in food-resource use between species is a key determinant of coexistence. These results have implications for our understanding of the coexistence of species in a world of limited resources. View Full-Text

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the survey also reveals substantial uncertainty about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, we find that many businesses are planning to apply for the new federal loans, but anticipate problems with the application process.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. View Full-Text

Interstellar grains are important for understanding the origin of the elements and the evolution of the solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for understanding the origin of the elements and the evolution of the solar system. They also provide constraints for the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the powered-artisanal fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. The ability to produce offspring is a fundamental characteristic of all animals. In humans, this ability is tightly regulated and limited by the mother’s metabolic power. Here, we show that the ability to produce offspring is also limited by the mother’s metabolic power in other mammals. We show that the ability to produce offspring is increased by the provision of resources to the mother, including allomaternal care and domestication. We also show that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work provides a new perspective on the evolution of reproduction and the evolution of domestication. View Full-Text

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in humans, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in MSA mice. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying treatment for MSA. The results also provide a proof of concept for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in the treatment of synucleinopathies. This would be a major advance in the field.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against pathogens and debris. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is constantly receiving information from the blood and the surrounding tissues. This information is processed and integrated into a coordinated response. The communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate information is poorly understood. Here, we show that the communication system is a highly connected network of cells that is organized in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between cells. This organization is effective for both local and global communication and is a small-world network. The small-world network is known to be effective for communication in biological systems, and our findings suggest that the endothelium is designed to be a small world.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are needed by many different audiences. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying software packages, and are described in detail in this paper. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers, policy makers, and the general public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate, muscle contraction, and neuronal signaling. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel for K+ over other ions. The activation gate is the channel’s main gate, and its closure is the main mechanism for the inactivation of the channel. We have identified a key residue in the activation gate that is involved in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This allosteric communication is crucial for the proper functioning of the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is constantly changing in response to the environment and the host. The composition of the gut microbiome is thought to be important for health, but the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are not well understood. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut produce a variety of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. These results provide a foundation for further investigation of the potential of anaerobic fungi to be used as a source of novel bioactive compounds.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders and is associated with a variety of social impairments. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We identified a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens in the development of a subordinate status. We also show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious rats. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the use of a single material phase and the development of structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses through the digital synthesis of multiple materials. The synthesized structures are digitally manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically realized. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with complex and programmable responses. The synthesized structures can be utilized for various applications, such as actuation, energy trapping, and sensing. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 microRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is involved in the regulation of hemoglobin expression. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed at high levels in fetal liver and low levels in adult bone marrow. We also show that IGF2BP1 is involved in the regulation of fetal hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies and to the regulation of fetal hemoglobin expression in pregnancy. This work also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. (Read more)

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy, and the survival of many patients is limited to a few years. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the mechanisms of resistance to therapy are diverse. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis is frequently mutated in cancer, and that this mutation confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We also found that this resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Thus, we propose that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the most important strategy to prevent heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate the store-operated Ca2+ channel (SOC) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which promotes vascular remodeling. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of the store-operated Ca2+ channel. This mechanism of action of LCCBs may explain the increased risk of heart failure in patients treated with LCCBs. Our data provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension in the elderly and patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. (Psy

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP has not yet succeeded in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our results also show that the early-seral ecosystem, which is the focus of the recently proposed Forest Service strategy, is not declining. However, the early-seral ecosystem is not a substitute for older forests, and the NWFP needs to continue to protect older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our results demonstrate the potential of computational drug design for the discovery of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training examples. In this work, we introduce a simple network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of parameters. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of parameters, and it is easier to train and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results for several segmentation problems with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The evolution of the African Rift System has been driven by the formation of one of the largest lakes in the world, Lake Malawi. This study presents a continuous, first-of-its-kind, 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the tropics, which shows that the evolution of the lake was driven by large-scale changes in the effective moisture of the climate system. The evolution of the lake is linked to a dramatic shift in the climate system at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, which is consistent with far-field climate forcing. The lake level variability is linked to eccentricity, and the evolution of the lake is linked to the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock. The evolution of the lake has had a profound influence on the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock. (Less)

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the last glacial cycle. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB samples is consistent with the terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. The YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite (Fe-Ni silicide) that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice leads to spontaneous lymphoproliferation, autoantibody production, and autoimmunity. This is not fatal, but leads to a more severe disease phenotype than congenital deficiency. This indicates that the adult loss of CTLA-4 is a compensatory mechanism to maintain tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their extraordinary diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species to trace the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls, which are the primary food source for most beetles. Our results show that the evolution of beetle diversity is driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls. These results have implications for our understanding of the evolution of animal diversity and the origins of plant-feeding habits in beetles. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the benefits of larger populations may be contingent on the level of individual skill and the degree of variation in the population. These results have implications for the design of future experiments and the evolution of technology in general. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE4 allele. APOE is a major protein of the brain and is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in the regulation of the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of a protein that is a component of senescent synapses, suggesting that APOE4 may be more susceptible to AD because of increased vulnerability of synapses to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be more susceptible to AD because of increased vulnerability of synapses to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is about 1,700 km in radius and has a density of 12.0–12.5 g/cm3. It is the densest solid in the solar system. The inner core is a mystery because it is not known how it formed. The most widely accepted model is that it formed by the solidification of a liquid core. However, this model is challenged by the fact that the required degree of undercooling is too large to be achieved in the core age. This contradiction is referred to as the inner core nucleation paradox. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate is a mechanism of the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors associated with chronic marijuana use.

Language is the most complex cognitive skill that humans have evolved. It is also the most complex natural phenomenon that the human brain has evolved to process. This raises the question of how the human brain processes language, which is the focus of this study. We show that the most powerful artificial neural network language models can predict the vast majority of the information that the human brain processes when processing language. This suggests that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are fundamentally computational in nature. We also show that the predictive processing that the models use to make these predictions is correlated with the accuracy of the models. These results provide computational evidence for the neuroscience of language. They also provide a new perspective for the future design of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear whether this success is due to the power of DL or to the fact that it is easier to train DL models than other models. In this paper, we show that the latter is the case. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies that the success of DL is due to the fact that it is easier to train such models than other models. Our results also imply a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a textbook example of the failure of governments and individuals to follow the advice of scientists. In this paper, we argue that this is not only due to a lack of scientific literacy but also to a lack of scientific understanding. We discuss a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We show that the experiment’s design is flawed in a way that was not recognized at the time and that undermines the conclusion. We conclude that the experiment should be taken out of the lore of social psychology and that the field should move on.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its etiology is still not fully understood. Here we report the genome sequence of a human pathogen that is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We also provide evidence that M. lepromatosis is a neuropathogenic pathogen. Our findings suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study also provides a framework for the study of ancient pathogens. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are the two key concepts standing at the foundations of quantum and statistical mechanics. The study of the time evolution of these quantities is a fundamental problem, which has been addressed in a variety of contexts. However, the dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is still a challenging problem, which has been addressed so far only for noninteracting systems. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. We provide a complete description of the dynamics of these quasiparticles, which is valid in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available is based on the replication-defective adenovirus vector, which requires a two-dose regimen and is associated with some side effects. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. This vaccine is highly attenuated, resulting in a milder disease in hamsters and a lower viral load in the lungs. In addition, the vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be administered as a single dose. These properties make the vaccine suitable for mass vaccination programs. We believe that this vaccine has the potential to be a valuable addition to the COVID-19 vaccine arsenal. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the history of plague. View Full-Text

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain numbers, which is the ultimate measure of brain processing capacity, has been largely ignored. This study fills this gap by providing a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of neuron numbers in amniotes, the group that includes birds and mammals. We show that the evolution of brain size in reptiles is not a general rule for other mammals but rather a consequence of the evolution of low neuron numbers. This has important implications for the study of the evolution of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The latter process is essential for many cellular processes, including cell motility. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is a small protein that can bind to actin filaments and induce their depolymerization. However, how it does so remains unclear. Here, we show that ADF can induce the depolymerization of actin filaments under physiological conditions, such as when they are connected to each other and under mechanical stress. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our observations. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the ADF mechanism and for the design of new drugs. They also have implications for our understanding of the ADF mechanism and for the design of new drugs.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and processed foods, is a major contributor to the rising epidemic of obesity in the United States. This study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of obesity and for the design of interventions to reduce fructose consumption. View Full-Text

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the history of the island in a new way. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We show that Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a well-established phenomenon. In this study, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can alter the bacterial translation system and human cells. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can have a significant impact on the translation of the mRNA. This study provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in the translation of mRNAs. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Under this energetic model, thermoregulatory costs constrain minimum size, whereas limitations on feeding efficiency constrain maximum size. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. (Less)

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human body is not known. We show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for understanding the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in the human body. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. Here we show that the surface-associated type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used both for twitching motility and as a sensor for surface attachment. We demonstrate that the mechanical activity of type IV pili is sensed by a mechanochemical mechanism that involves the interaction of the chemosensory protein PilJ with the pilin subunit of type IV pili. Our results thus provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of type IV pili in surface sensing and demonstrate that this process is used by bacteria for surface-specific motility and pathogenicity. This work also provides a new perspective on the role of type IV pili in bacterial motility and surface attachment. View Full-Text

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of these chemicals on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread and that the concentrations of these chemicals are often high enough to cause harm to aquatic organisms. Our results suggest that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Thus, there is an urgent need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This will help to ensure the sustainable use of these important tools for agriculture and protect the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2. The world is moving toward a low-carbon future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, which are not present in all AD cases. Here, we show that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons is the primary cause of the immune response in AD. We demonstrate that neurons are the source of the majority of the proinflammatory factors in AD, and that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons is the primary cause of the neuroinflammation in AD. Our findings have important implications for the development of novel AD therapeutics. View Full-Text

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for its use for economic purposes is, however, still unknown. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied for many years. We find that the folding of maltose binding protein is a multistep process.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to RNA caps, which are required for their biological activity. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme that removes the cap of Np4-capped RNAs in bacteria is also the predominant enzyme that removes capped transcripts in the absence of Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme, RppH, prefers capped substrates over their capped counterparts, and the cap is removed by a mechanism that is distinct from the one used to remove other 5′ termini. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, the mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression are not fully understood. Here we show that arginine, a major amino acid, is a key molecule in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function. Our results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This strategy could be extended to other immune-mediated diseases. View Full-Text

The biomass of the biosphere is the main component of the global carbon cycle and is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and that the mass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, where systems with no external control parameter oscillate between two or more qualitatively different states. SOC systems are characterized by the fact that the rate of change of the system state is proportional to the system state itself. This paper is about a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the well-known sandpile model. We show that the model is a continuous version of a pattern-formation system, which is a mathematical model of the growth of a population of species. We also show that the model is related to the theory of proportional growth.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings also provide a new paradigm for machine learning of electronic and phonon structures of materials. This work is expected to advance the understanding of the electronic and phonon structures of materials, and to promote the development of new materials.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of new strategies for the control of plant fungal diseases. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, NCR peptides, which are expressed in the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. We show that the NCR044 peptide is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It is a unique peptide in terms of its structural architecture and mode of action. The discovery of this new class of antifungal peptides will be of great interest for the development of new strategies for the control of plant fungal diseases. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome immediately after mating, suggesting that the female reproductive tract provides a critical environment for sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for hemostasis. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on platelets, in a reaction triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We also show that force application switches A1 and/or GPIbα to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This work provides a mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF and may be useful for the design of new therapies for VWD. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered efforts to understand the role of viruses in human health. We present a database of human-associated viruses, which is the most comprehensive to date. We also provide a resource for the analysis of existing datasets, which can be used to identify new virus–disease associations. This database will enable future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI process is very complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is mainly due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. The HSRL is capable of providing a unique view of the ACI process. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL by conducting a case study over Beijing. The observations show that the aerosol loading increased the droplet number concentration and decreased the droplet effective radius, which is consistent with the expectation. However, the aerosol-induced increase in cloud water was canceled out by enhanced evaporation, which is a new finding. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. View Project

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense debate. The temperature of the surface of the Earth at the time of its formation is of particular interest because it is believed to have had a profound effect on the evolution of life. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the early Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth was lower than previously thought. This finding has important implications for the origin of life on Earth. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. Despite the availability of antimalarial drugs, the disease remains a major health problem. The malaria parasite exploits the host cell’s biophysical properties to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses its own surface antigens to alter the biophysical properties of the host cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding has implications for the development of new antimalarial strategies.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is used in a wide range of applications, including sensors, lasers, and electronics. However, its electronic properties can be changed by external stimuli, such as pressure, electric field, and light. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic bandgap can be completely vanished, without phonon instability. This work provides a new route to control the electronic properties of diamond. It also provides a new perspective to understand the origin of the metallization of diamond. It is expected to provide new opportunities for diamond applications in the future.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Despite the availability of antiviral drugs, there is no vaccine or antiviral agent that can prevent influenza infection. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. We show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza challenge. We also show that low humidity impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Thus, our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the impact of dry air on influenza infection and disease outcome, and suggests that dry air may be a potential target for influenza control. The brain is thought to build a hierarchical representation of the structure of a sentence, from the simplest to the most complex syntactic units. However, there is no direct evidence that this process actually takes place. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be important for language comprehension and may be disrupted in language disorders. Our findings may also have implications for the neurobiology of language acquisition. Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the pathway. This is a unique feature that can be used to fine-tune the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit that includes the ventral tegmental area (VTA), the nucleus accumbens, and the locus coeruleus. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, this system may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a key goal for sustainable food production. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial signaling system that allows the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal crop. This system provides a platform for the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to engineer a sustainable nitrogen cycle in agriculture. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed forest monitoring systems are used to detect and track deforestation, but the systems are often not used to their full potential. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses remote-sensed alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests and reduce deforestation. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the complexity of the program and the difficulty of measuring the effects of the program. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their bodies to perceive the world around them. However, some animals, such as spiders, can perceive the world without a body. This study shows that the spider can perceive sound without a body by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured acoustic antenna that is much more sensitive than the spider’s body. The spider can also adjust the size of the web to suit its needs. This study provides a unique model for studying the outsourcing of hearing, the supersizing of sensing, and the regeneration of hearing organs. It also provides a new way to perceive sound in the world. (Show more)

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that the health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions are much larger than previously thought. This is because fossil-fuel-related emissions are responsible for most of the excess mortality from outdoor air pollution and for the majority of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions are further enhanced by reducing nonfossil anthropogenic sources, such as biomass burning and emissions from the cement and steel industries. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. Vaccine development has been rapid, but the global distribution of vaccines remains uneven. We report a recombinant protein that can be expressed in large quantities and that can be used to construct a virus-like particle vaccine. This protein can be used to develop vaccines that can be manufactured in large quantities, which will be needed to meet the global demand for vaccines.

The role of ALK in the development of human cancer is well established. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK are activated by zebrafish ALKALs. We also show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/Ltk family receptors by ALKALs and their involvement in neural crest development. These findings may help to understand the role of ALK/Ltk in cancer and in the development of other tissues. They also provide a model system for studying the role of ALK/Ltk in the development of other tissues. This study also provides a potential target for the development of new therapeutics for cancer and pigment cell diseases. (Show more)

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the cause of plague, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the timing and geographic spread of its evolution are still debated. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the early stages of its evolution. Our results show that the evolution of Y. pestis was not a sudden event but rather a series of steps, which allowed us to reconstruct a picture of its early development. We also discovered the presence of a flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide new insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship with its vector. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (i.e., hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. We found that, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The management of agricultural systems can affect the storage of soil organic carbon (SOC) in the long term. However, the effects of different management practices on SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions are highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase the storage of SOC and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions in the long term. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon in the long term and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. This framework can be used to assess the potential of agricultural systems to mitigate climate change and to develop strategies for the restoration of degraded agricultural lands. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to identifying and prioritizing the threat of emerging viruses. We developed a framework to assess the risk of spillover and spread of viruses from animals to humans. We then used this framework to prioritize 887 viruses from 171 species of animals. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting database, SpillOver, is a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. (Less)

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts animals, but the mechanisms that underlie its production are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a previously unknown mechanism for the production of a red pigment in nectar. This work provides a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of this trait in plants and vertebrates.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men generally resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. We conclude that the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is more complex than previously thought. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand of DNA. In humans, pol δ is the only polymerase that is responsible for this process. In S. cerevisiae, the stability of pol δ is essential for every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a unique model for studying the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme in humans. This model could be used to study the role of pol δ in human diseases. It could also be used to study the role of PCNA in human diseases.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the RNA world hypothesis, the first form of life was based on RNA molecules, rather than on proteins. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. This polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers and ribozymes. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme is a key component of the RNA world hypothesis and a step toward the synthesis of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in any city over time. The clinical characteristics of severe and critical patients with COVID-19 are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of these patients are identified. The pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality. The results provide a new therapeutic strategy for severe and critical patients with COVID-19. The study also provides a reference for the treatment of other cytokine storm diseases.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also a highly toxic metal that must be tightly regulated. In fungi, the role of the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in copper homeostasis has been established, but the existence of copper-binding analogs of the xanthocillin siderophore in fungi has not been demonstrated. Here we show that the xan BGC is expressed in Aspergillus fumigatus, and that the xan BGC isocyanide products bind copper and impact intracellular copper pools. Copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC isocyanide products were demonstrated in coculture experiments, and the ability of xanthocillin to be detoxified by copper was confirmed. These results suggest that the xan BGC is involved in fungal interactions with competing microbes and provide a mechanism for the existence of fungal natural products that bind copper. This knowledge may be useful for the development of antifungal strategies. (Show more)

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly related to the evolutionary strategies of plants. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is not clear. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in recipients of a Th17 transfer, indicating that they are not the primary drivers of disease. Instead, Th17 cells were required for the development of a subset of Th1-like cells, which were the primary drivers of disease. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the development of novel therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic causes, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. We report a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients. These cells can be used to study the disease and to screen for drugs that can alleviate the toxicity of astrocytes in ALS. This will help us to understand the disease and to develop new therapies.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that is expressed by the tick Ixodes scapularis and that alters the composition of the tick microbiota. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and the gut barrier, which are critical obstacles for the colonization of the tick by the pathogen. These data provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the host microbiota and suggest that targeting the host microbiota may be a strategy for controlling vector-borne diseases. Birds are one of the most successful groups of animals on Earth. However, the origin of the modern avian bauplan is still a matter of debate. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This taxon adds important information about the origin of the modern avian tail and its evolution leading to the loss of the tail.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the atmosphere. In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are cryptic, meaning that they are difficult to see. The color of a vertebrate is determined by the absorption spectrum of its pigments, which are mostly proteins. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) is determined by the absorption spectrum of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main product of the catabolism of the blood pigment, hemoglobin. Our results provide a molecular basis for the evolution of green coloration in anurans and a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. They also provide a molecular explanation for the evolution of green coloration in other vertebrates, such as dinosaurs and birds. Finally, they provide a molecular explanation for the evolution of green coloration in plants. View Full-Text

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which is a m6A demethylase. ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in a HIF-dependent manner, and is associated with the enrichment of breast cancer cells in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study provides a mechanism for the maintenance of cancer stem cells in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment, and suggests a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. (Show more)

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We show that the use of fetal animal skins for parchment is not supported by the data.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the event, the carbon cycle reorganization, and the recovery dynamics are well constrained. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Abridged)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We found that RORα deletion leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs), which results in excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides insights into the epigenetic regulation of NF-κB signaling and suggests therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation for the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease.
