The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in the spike protein of currently circulating viruses. We show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase the infectivity of the virus. This may be important for understanding the increased transmissibility of the Delta variant. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the well-known result for finite games. It also provides a new proof of the existence of an ε-equilibrium in a class of games that includes the repeated prisoner’s dilemma. Our proof is simpler than the existing proofs, and it applies to games with countably infinite sets of players.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical potential of an electron is the driving force of chemical reactions. The chemical hardness is the resistance to the flow of electrons. Both properties are fundamental to chemistry, and they are the basis of the chemical potential theory. We show that both properties decrease with pressure, and we show that the chemical properties of atoms change dramatically under pressure. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be predicted by our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.

Fire is a key driver of the global carbon cycle, but the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of human demography in shaping the future of the global carbon cycle and the potential for climate–carbon cycle feedbacks to slow global warming. Our study also shows that climate change is likely to increase ignitions, which could exacerbate the effects of climate change on fire regimes. This highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the feedbacks between climate, fire, and the carbon cycle to inform climate policy. (Abridged)

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic relationships. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is precisely timed to coincide with the maturation of the symbiotic organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thereby able to maintain a healthy population level and to produce light at night. Our results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic relationships. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as sequences of patterns. We use this method to identify topics in a corpus of narratives about violent deaths. We show that our method can identify topics that are not captured by existing structured variables. We also show that our topics are gendered and that this gendering is related to the gendering of the semantic space in which the topics are embedded. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. It can also be used to identify the gendering of topics in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the Mediterranean in the 14th century, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease spread over four centuries. We show that this interpretation is incomplete. Our analysis of climate fluctuations in Europe and Asia reveals that the disease was introduced repeatedly into European harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the disease was spread by humans, rather than by a single introduction event. Our results have important implications for our understanding of the spread of the plague and its impact on medieval society. (Abridged)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. However, the population dynamics of asteroid species are currently under threat from a disease that has been spreading rapidly along the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus and that it is the most likely cause of the mass mortality events. This study provides a clear example of the impact of human activities on the functioning of marine ecosystems.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of blood cancer, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies for AML, ideally targeting the disease at its stem cell origin. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, allowing us to study the genomic diversity of the Malagasy people. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we show that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy people and their history. It also provides a framework for studying the genomic diversity of other island populations. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. We also found that the RNA base pairs with the cadA and galE promoters and that the base pairing interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the subjective assessments of thousands of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is statistically robust and maintains similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the survey data can be used to provide a more accurate and timely assessment of crop conditions, which can be used to improve agricultural decision-making and food security. This work provides a framework for using the vast network of “people as sensors” that exists in the form of crop experts to improve the use of citizen science data in agricultural monitoring.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding problem in language processing. It also suggests a mechanism for the formation of memory traces that can be used to explain the effects of context and serial order in language processing. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Abridged)

The origin of life is a fundamental question in biology. The origin of plastids, the double-membrane organelles that are the site of photosynthesis, is a key step in the origin of life. The origin of the plastid genome, the genetic material of photosynthetic organisms, is a key step in the origin of plastids. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the origin of plastids is a process of stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. This process may have been facilitated by the modular organization of the plastid genome. View Full-Text

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Abridged)
The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, provides a unique link between the atomic age and the age of science.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a major feature of neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a hallmark of multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the development of neurodegeneration, and it is well known that neuroinflammation is regulated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase 1 (ASK1). In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of neuroinflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a rodent model of MS. We also found that ASK1 plays a major role in the later stage of EAE, suggesting that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of EAE and suggest that ASK1 may be a potential therapeutic target for neuroinflammation in MS. This study also provides a rationale for further investigation of the role of ASK1 in other neuroinflammatory diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to the influence of human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad spectrum of symptoms. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. These results provide a mechanistic understanding of the autism spectrum disorder and suggest that the inhibition of Rac1-dependent forgetting may be a therapeutic target for autism. This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. It is also the first to our knowledge to examine the extent to which individual differences in reaction to news content may be related to personality. Results suggest that, on average, people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. They also suggest that individual differences in personality may be related to the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. These findings may help explain the prevalence of negative news content around the world. They may also suggest that there is reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” (PsycINFO Database Record

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 (p.R304W) associated with Stormorken syndrome, and in ORAI1 (p.P245L), associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged form of the polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading of neurodegenerative disease. They also provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of spreading of other types of aggregates in other diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the mechanisms that facilitate virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a highly concentrated immunosuppressant protein (MTX) in the bat submandibular salivary gland. MTX selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings may help to elucidate the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats and provide a new strategy for the development of antiviral drugs. This article is protected by copyright. Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway supporting this growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking colon cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We also show that this inhibitor is particularly effective in blocking the growth of B-cell cancer cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell cancer. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone, and the inclusions formed by these proteins are characteristic of the neuropathology of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but are themselves supersaturated in motor neurons. We propose that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the neuropathology of ALS and suggests a mechanism for the formation of inclusions in this disease. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, which can be used to study many-body physics. The photonic crystals can also be used to control the emission of light, which can be used to study the interaction between light and matter. The Cretaceous period is often considered to be a time of great change, with the evolution of dinosaurs, flowering plants, and mammals. However, the evolution of flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of the angiosperms, the group that includes most of the world’s flowering plants, is poorly understood in particular. Here we present a detailed analysis of Montsechia, a plant that was first discovered in the early 20th century. We show that Montsechia is an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that it is sister to Ceratophyllum. This opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the evolution of some early flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using genetic sequences from modern viruses. However, the evolutionary history of viruses is likely to be different from that of their hosts, and it is therefore important to study viruses from the past. Here we present 10 ancient viral genomes from humans that lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This acceleration is a clear indication that the climate system is changing. The acceleration is not due to short-term natural variability, and it is not fully explained by the increase in global mean temperature. The acceleration is consistent with the climate models’ projections of the response to increasing atmospheric greenhouse gases.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In particular, the study of the transition states and transition-state-like species that are the focus of this paper is a key step in understanding the mechanism of action of enzymes. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the transition-state-like species in tryptophan synthase. This study demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme mechanisms. This approach can be extended to other enzymes and other reaction intermediates. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a zoonotic coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog that inhibits viral replication, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, given the current global spread of this virus. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is the trigger for the maturation of a symbiotic organ in the squid Euprymna scolopes. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbionts, which are able to use it to maintain a healthy symbiosis. This glycan provision and catabolism is a mechanism by which animals can control the activities of their specific symbionts. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbioses and the potential for the use of glycans as a means of controlling the activities of specific microbes. (Show more)

This research shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved through simple interventions. The results have implications for the way we think about the causes and consequences of school suspensions.

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are major contributors to the mutagenesis of the genome. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct pol II stalling profiles. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. MERS-CoV infects human cells only after its spike (S) proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. Here, we show that the first cleavages are required for MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but have little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Our findings may help to explain why MERS-CoV causes severe disease in humans, but not in other animal species. (Show more)

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large proportion of obesity and other diet-related diseases. This study shows that it is possible to make a significant contribution to both of these problems by simply changing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a catering environment. This approach could be applied in a wide range of settings, including hospitals, schools, and workplaces. It could also be used to test the effectiveness of other interventions to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in catering environments. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal risk of electoral harm. They also suggest that the benefits of vote-by-mail may be larger than previously thought. Our results are consistent with the idea that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be used to mitigate the effects of the pandemic and other crises.

SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic. The role of accessory proteins in the pathogenesis of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is formed through a unique sequence, 73YIDI76, which is also the basis of a noncovalent interface. These interfaces show how SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 can form unique large-scale assemblies not possible for SARS-CoV, potentially mediating unique immune suppression and evasion activities. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the severe and rapid spread of the disease. They also provide a target for vaccine development. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. We also show that CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cerebral edema. The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This requires that we be able to assess the strength of the associations that we find. Unfortunately, the data that we collect are often too large and the methods for analyzing them too sophisticated to allow us to assess the strength of all the associations that we find. We describe a new approach to selective inference that allows us to set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We illustrate the approach using forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The approach can be applied to any statistical learning method.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of fibroblasts into functional ECs. ETV2 is able to induce the expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and to induce expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Furthermore, ETV2 significantly improves blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) were identified as oncogenes. Recently, two ligands were discovered that bind to and activate Alk and Ltk. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function of these ligands and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that the two ligands encoded by the zebrafish genome are essential for the development of iridophores, which are specialized cells that contribute to the coloration of the skin and the eye. These results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands in vivo. It also provides a model system for studying the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands in other organisms. This study may also lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for cancer and other diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the treatment of T2D is still challenging. In this study, we found that STING plays a role in the regulation of insulin secretion in β-cells and insulin target tissues. Our study provides a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction resulted in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses is limited. Our results provide insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging mechanism of the influenza A virus. They also provide a molecular basis for the evolution of the influenza A virus. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of a complex interplay between the local hemodynamic environment and the local expression of genes. Here we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This strategy may be applicable to other diseases that are regulated by YAP/TAZ. The study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of disturbed flow-induced vascular homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis and other diseases regulated by YAP/TAZ. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been shaped by humans for millennia. However, the role of humans in increasing wildfire activity is largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. Our findings highlight the need for a more nuanced understanding of the role of humans in shaping the fire regime. This is particularly important in the context of climate change, which has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity. Our results also highlight the need for a more nuanced understanding of the role of humans in shaping the fire regime. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in any city over time. It can also be used to measure the physical changes in any neighborhood within a city over time. This method can be used to measure the physical changes in any city over time. Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. View Full-Text

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is one of the most severe consequences of this breakdown and is currently affecting large areas of the world’s reefs. We show that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress is a key process in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. This process is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which in turn is a direct consequence of the heat stress-induced metabolic demand of the coral host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis under future environmental conditions. This may ultimately help us to conserve this unique and valuable ecosystem. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In the context of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky, allowing the dissemination of cancer cells to other parts of the body. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can also affect the composition of the gut microbiome, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a loss of the epithelial barrier. We also show that the microbiome can restore the integrity of the epithelium, and that this process can be used to extend the lifespan of the organism. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a new strategy for the treatment of cancer and aging. View Full-Text

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. In this study, we show that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in breast cancer cells and is up-regulated following chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 is involved in the development of breast cancer and that targeting ROR1 with an antibody may improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. However, this attribution is based on a single paleoclimate proxy, and the mechanism is not supported by other proxies. Here we show that the start of deglaciation is instead linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that river fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that they are particularly important for the poor and undernourished. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our results underscore the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost, and the few remaining neurons are unable to effectively repair after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery opens the door to a new form of regeneration that can be harnessed for therapeutic purposes. Moreover, we show that this form of regeneration is triggered by a physical lesion of a sensory neuron, which is a common mechanism for inducing regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. These findings suggest that the adult nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the mechanisms that regulate regeneration in the adult nervous system are more similar than previously thought. We propose that the mechanisms that regulate regeneration in the adult nervous system are more similar than previously thought.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. It is also a source of variation in many traits, including disease resistance. The distribution of recombination across the genome is therefore of fundamental importance. Here, we describe the location of recombination events in a wild population of the flowering plant Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, which are interspersed with cold regions. The distribution of recombination in Mimulus is similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the general pattern of recombination across the genome has been conserved since the origin of eukaryotes.

The resting brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to reflect the structure of the underlying neuronal connectivity. However, the definition of these networks is still a matter of debate. Here, we used a multimodal approach to identify and validate a resting state network topography in healthy subjects and in Parkinson’s disease patients. We found that the dominant resting state network was similar to the default mode network, which is thought to be inactive during the day-to-day spontaneous activity of the brain. In contrast, a second resting state network was found to be more active in Parkinson’s disease, and this pattern was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. These results provide a new perspective on the organization of the resting brain, which can be used to study the functional significance of the different resting state networks.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because it is also found on pre-mRNAs. This discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes raises the possibility that it could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a promising target for the treatment of diabetes complications. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years in people with diabetes, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results may help to identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of diabetes complications.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, and that some of them develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the disease and in the maintenance of the behavioral symptoms. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. View Full-Text

Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and the quality of their flavor is of great importance to consumers. The biosynthesis of the volatiles that contribute to the flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also provide evidence that this gene is involved in the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in plants. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of these important plant volatiles. It also opens the door to the development of new strategies for improving the flavor of tomato and other fruit crops. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these two factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. (Abridged)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit, which is involved in spatial memory. The organization of MEC is important for understanding the formation of spatial representations in the brain. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are the main cell type in the MEC, are spatially organized and form a network. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its relationship with other brain regions. They also provide a platform for future studies of the formation of spatial representations in the brain. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here we show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra project to the striatum in a system that is affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. We also show that the dopamine neurons of the substantia nigra form specialized integrative units within the system that are not found in other regions of the brain. These findings have implications for our understanding of the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated the felt connection. We found that the speed with which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. Within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This is a fundamental question in social science, and our findings provide a simple answer. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for setting the heart rate, which is critical for maintaining blood pressure and other vital functions. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia that is associated with an increased risk of stroke and death. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is selectively expressed in SANCs and is required for their Ca2+ stores. We also show that STIM1 regulates Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs by modulating the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry channels and the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for treating atrial fibrillation. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well established, its role in plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact with each other in the priming of defense responses against insect herbivores. These findings provide insights into the role of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the regulation of macrophage activation. They also suggest that modulation of the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase could be a therapeutic approach for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This approach could be particularly useful for the treatment of autoimmune diseases, where the activation of macrophages is a major problem.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding problem in language processing. It also suggests a mechanism for the formation of memory traces that can be used to explain the emergence of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and medicine for the human race. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics and diagnostics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution is one of the most pervasive threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from nonpoint sources, such as agricultural runoff and urban stormwater. However, these sources are often difficult to quantify and manage. In this study, we show that small tributaries of large lakes can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, which are often overlooked in current management strategies. This approach could help to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems. (Show more)

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is coupled to an environment that makes work available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. Our results suggest that the ability to absorb work from the environment may be a key property for the emergence of complex behavior in chemical systems.

The mechanisms underlying the generation of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the effects of an antibody against the NMDA receptor can change the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We also show that the same changes in microcircuitry can lead to overt paroxysmal EEG abnormalities when the same changes in microcircuitry are allowed in a control condition. These findings offer insights into the mechanisms underlying the generation of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. They also suggest that the same treatment that is used to treat the underlying disease may be used to treat the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This treatment is already widely used in the clinic. Thus, our findings may have important clinical implications. (PsycINFO Database Record

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was associated with an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean and with an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results have implications for our understanding of the history of abrupt climate change and the potential for future abrupt climate change. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a panacea for the palm oil industry, but it is an important tool for reducing deforestation. We also show that certification is not a substitute for other policies that reduce deforestation, such as the moratorium on new concessions. Our results highlight the importance of certification in the context of other policies and the need for more rigorous evaluation of certification’s impact on deforestation. (Less)

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex is determined by multiple loci, resulting in more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple sex determination alleles can produce a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. They also suggest that the maintenance of multiple sex determination alleles in a species may be a key to the evolution of higher-order sexual polymorphism. (Show more)

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of the lipofuscin pigments, which are formed from the photooxidation of vitamin A aldehyde intermediates. These intermediates are also formed from photooxidation of the bisretinoid A2E, which is a key intermediate in the photooxidation of rhodopsin. We show that the accumulation of these lipofuscin pigments and bisretinoids is reduced in mice treated with a chelator of intracellular iron. This reduction in accumulation is associated with reduced photooxidation of these pigments. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, which is associated with accumulation of lipofuscin pigments. They also suggest that the photooxidation of rhodopsin and its intermediates may be a target for the treatment of retinal diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. The evolution of their tentacles has been considered a dead end, as they are highly specialized for prey capture. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentacles is not only linked to prey type, but also to the evolution of the nematocysts that are used to capture prey. Our results suggest that the evolution of the tentacles and nematocysts is linked to the evolution of the prey itself, and that the evolution of the tentacles is not a dead end. This study contributes to understanding the evolution of specialization in food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the evolution of the hand is fragmentary, however, and the earliest hominin fossils are too fragmentary to provide a clear picture of the evolution of the hand. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand that is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand. The fossil also suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human hand function. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of this process. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, and thus defective glycine metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. These findings provide a rationale for the use of formate as a therapeutic to treat cancer. They also provide a rationale for the use of formate as a therapeutic to treat cancer.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. Our findings also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to food and nutrition security that considers the role of natural landscapes such as forests in improving people’s diets. This study also provides a model for how to conduct causal inference research in the social sciences. We used a modeling approach that combined two-way fixed-effects regression analysis with covariate balancing generalized propensity score (CBGPS) weighting, which allowed for causal inferences to be made. This approach can be used in future studies to improve the quality of causal inference research in the social sciences. (PsycINFO Database Record

Modern agriculture is a major driver of global change, with the expansion of mechanization being one of the most important drivers of this change. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a significant increase in the risk of subsoil compaction, which has now become a major concern for sustainable agriculture. We developed a global map of subsoil compaction risk, based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
